Description: Upper body sherd of North Ionian (possibly Clazomenian) black-figured pottery neck-amphora; exterior: black-figure decoration consisting of female figure (part of head with added white on flesh, ear with spoked-wheel earring, hair and bead necklace remaining) to right.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Greco-Roman Museum, Alexandria. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

According to Venit (1988, p. 44-45, no. 159) the sherd is unlikely to be from Clazomenae because the hairstyle is not typical of the production. For similar spoked-wheel earrings, see British Museum 1886,0401.1256.
Bibliographic references: Venit 1988 / Greek Painted Pottery from Naukratis in Egyptian Museums (p. 44-5, pl. 38, no. 159)
Möller 2000 / Naukratis, Trade in Archaic Greece (p. 260)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GG.598)
